awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mergers of Massive Black Holes at the Centers of Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigators will explore how black holes (BHs) grow and shine over long timescales.  Most galaxies have enormous black holes at their centers, surrounded by stars, planets, dust, and ionized gas.  Stars formed by this material can also feed the black hole.  These black holes have masses that are up to billions of times the mass of the Sun.  Galaxies repeatedly merge with other galaxies during their lifetimes.  Thus, super massive black hole pairs form frequently.  These pairs of black holes make ripples in space and time called gravitational waves.   As such, they are prime targets for gravitational wave detectors.  Gravitational wave simulations provide a new way to explore the Universe.  The investigators' computer simulations will help determine how black hole binaries interact with surrounding material.  The investigators' simulations will help astronomers detect merging black holes and understand the regions surrounding the black holes.  The investigators will train students and develop new numerical codes that can be used for a wide variety of science and engineering applications.

The investigators will numerically simulate the long-term merger dynamics of supermassive black hole binaries (SMBHB) with disks of gas, planets, and stars surrounding the black holes.  The investigators will model, in detail, the hydrodynamical reaction of the disk to the orbital motion of the SMBHBs as well as the back-reaction of the disk on this orbital motion.  These theorists seek to answer several questions important for understanding astronomical observations.  They will model the time it takes for the two black holes to merge in the presence of different types of gas disks.  Observationally, it is important to estimate how bright the region surrounding the SMBHB will be during merger.  The results will be applied to interpret observations of the stochastic gravitational wave background, periodicities in quasar light-curves in large time-domain surveys, and gravitational wave strength of stellar-mass BHs.

por.por_cntn:
Most galaxies harbor supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in their nuclei, and experience numerous mergers in their lifetimes. As a result, SMBH binaries are a robust prediction of galaxy formation theories and an important ingredient of galaxy evolution. They are also prime targets for future gravitational wave (GW) experiments. However, the details of the SMBH merger process, the demography of the resulting binary SMBH population, and how the merger phase relates to SMBH growth and to observed activity in galactic nuclei (AGN), all remain unknown.  The lack of observational evidence for compact sub-parsec binaries suggests that the binary orbits quickly decay to unresolvable spatial separations.


In this proposal, we developed theoretical models and observational diagnostics for compact SMBH binaries, based on a detailed study of circumbinary gas dynamics, using the state-of-the-art simulation software developed through this award.  Our key results are the following:


(1) The circumbinary gas disk, in most circumstances, helps drive a wide binary towards merger.  The binary settles to an elliptical (rather than circular) orbit, while continuously shrinking its separation, due to the torques exerted by the gas.   This rapid orbital decay helps explain the dearth of binaries at resolvable angular separations, and suggests that most of these binary SMBHs will ultimately merge via GW emission.

(2) Binary black holes are fueled very differently from single black holes. The fueling rate of the individual BH components, and the corresponding brightness of these objects on the sky, fluctuates periodically, following the binary's orbital period.    These periodic fluctuations persist all the way to the merger of the two BHs. In addition to the periodic fluctuations, we showed that gravitational lensing can cause distinct recurring flares, whenever the binary orbital plane is observed not too far from edge-on. Furthermore, the shadows of the individual BHs often produces a distinct dip near the peak of these flares, facilitating the novel detection of BH shadows.    The spectra of binaries is also found to be different from AGN powered by solitary SMBHs, due to the shocks that occur in the gravitationally disturbed gas.    Using these phenomena, we have identified 33 compact SMBH binary  candidates, with orbital periods of around a year, in a large time-domain dataset (the Palomar Transient Factory).

(3) We also showed that the presence of circumbinary gas can subtly alter the binary's orbit even close to the merger, when it is decaying due to the emission of strong GWs.  The gas therefore can imprint a characteristic drift feature on the GWs emitted by these inspiraling objects.   This suggests that GW sources discovered by the future LISA satellite can be used to reveal the presence of circumbinary gas, on spatial scales unresolvable by traditional telescopes.

In addition to the above, most of our theoretical results and predictions can be scaled down to apply to smaller, stellar-mass black holes.   We have studied the demography and nature of  stellar-mass BH binaries embedded in the accretion disks of bright AGN.   We showed that binaries can be captured by these disks, and can also form in the disk.  Once a binary is embedded in the AGN accretion disk, it will migrate toward to central SMBH, while its orbital separation decays.   The resulting population of BH binary mergers can explain several puzzling properties of the BH-BH mergers discovered through GWs in the last few years by the LIGO-Virgo collaboration.  In particular, multiple mergers can hierarchically build up unusually large BH masses, and frequent scattering between compact binaries and a third, single BH can induce nonzero orbital eccentricities as well as a tilt between the orbital plane and the spin direction of the BHs.   These characteristics can be used in large future samples of GW events to identify this novel pathway to BH-BH coalescence.


This collaborative award significantly strengthened the ties between astrophysics research at Columbia and NYU, and also had broad impact on time-domain astronomy and GW astronomy. The codes (DISCO, Mara, and Sailfish) developed throughout this award have been made available to the research community, and can be applied by other scientists to hydrodynamics problems beyond the topic of this proposal.   Finally, we have partnered with LinkNYC, and during Astronomy month in April 2022, some of our results were displayed throughout the streets of New York City, on the ubiquitous digital displays / WiFi towers, with brief explanations aimed at piquing the interest of the general public (see attached image).
